body: strerror_r() has two versions: GNU-specific and XSI-compliant. The XSI version always stores the string in the provided buffer, but the GNU version might store it in the provided buffer or it might use some immutable static buffer instead. Since we always free the error string, we might end up freeing the immutable static buffer. https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/strerror.3.html Fixes #1967 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/1948)

comment_data.body: Aha, so we do have a min macro. Actually, it's not even a macro but a function. Feels a bit weird treating `size_t` as `uint32_t`, but I guess it works...
Can you also add a null check?
Maybe we should do this differently: allocate a buffer on the stack and then copy it into `str`, unconditionally. That way we can avoid this non-portable pointer compare.

I have no idea what you are saying. Why is this pointer comparison non-portable? How a stack buffer would help when `strerror_r()` is allowed to return an internal buffer instead of using our stack buffer, so we would have the same issue over again?

___ *[toxcore/network.c, line 1736 at r2](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/1948#-MuvKoSx-zAetf48l7te:-MuxeBvW-qm6v0A94SfS:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/260ecbe038d3c04f03dae842a6a08014092ee1ea/toxcore/network.c#L1736)):*
Previously, JFreegman wrote…
If `copy_len` is equal to 256 it will overflow the `str` buffer. This is because you only allocate 256 bytes to str, which includes the null terminating byte. In order to make this code more clear I'd use a constant in place of `256`, and allocate the buffer with a + 1 byte for the null: `#define MAX_LEN 256` `char *str = malloc(MAX_LEN + 1)` Then null termination is straight forward: `str[MAX_LEN] = '\0'`
Done.

commit.message:
Fix potential freeing of an immutable static buffer

strerror_r() has two versions: GNU-specific and XSI-compliant. The XSI
version always stores the string in the provided buffer, but the GNU
version might store it in the provided buffer or it might use some
immutable static buffer instead. Since we always free the error string,
we might end up freeing the immutable static buffer.

Fix potential freeing of an immutable static buffer

strerror_r() has two versions: GNU-specific and XSI-compliant. The XSI
version always stores the string in the provided buffer, but the GNU
version might store it in the provided buffer or it might use some
immutable static buffer instead. Since we always free the error string,
we might end up freeing the immutable static buffer.
